You can <g1>profile</g1> your project to check its runtime performance and find problems.
Use the Stride <g2>Game Profiler</g2> script or an external profiling tool such as the Performance Profiler in Visual Studio.
Use the Stride <g2>Game Profiler</g2> script or an external profiling tool such as the Performance Profiler in Visual Studio.
Profile with the Stride <g1>Game Profiler</g1> script
Profile with the Stride <g1>Game Profiler</g1> script
The <g1>Game Profiler</g1> script shows how performance costs change at runtime.
The <g1>Game Profiler</g1> script shows how performance costs change at runtime.
This helps isolate bottlenecks and find their cause.
This helps isolate bottlenecks and find their cause.
In the <g1>Asset View</g1>, click <x1/>Add new asset button<x2/> and select <g2>Scripts > Game Profiler</g2>.
In the <g1>Asset View</g1>, click <x1/>Add new asset button<x2/> and select <g2>Scripts > Game Profiler</g2>.
Leave the default information and click <g2>Create script</g2>.
Leave the default information and click <g2>Create script</g2>.
Game Studio adds the GameProfiler script to your project.
Game Studio adds the GameProfiler script to your project.
Add the script to an entity.

Select the entity that contains the <g1>GameProfiler</g1>.
Select the entity that contains the <g1>GameProfiler</g1>.
In the <g1>Property Grid</g1> (on the right by default), enable the <g2>Game Profiler</g2> component.
In the <g1>Property Grid</g1> (on the right by default), enable the <g2>Game Profiler</g2> component.
You can also enable and disable the profiler at runtime with <g1>Left Ctrl + Left Shift + P</g1>.
You can also enable and disable the profiler at runtime with <g1>Left Ctrl + Left Shift + P</g1>.
The Game Profiler shows profiling results as your game runs.
The Game Profiler shows profiling results as your game runs.
This gives you the true profiling values, ignoring sync time.
This gives you the true profiling values, ignoring sync time.
To change the Game Profiler properties, select the <g1>GameProfiler</g1> entity and use the <g2>Property Grid</g2>.
To change the Game Profiler properties, select the <g1>GameProfiler</g1> entity and use the <g2>Property Grid</g2>.
The kind of information the profiler displays (FPS only, CPU, or GPU).
The kind of information the profiler displays (FPS only, CPU, or GPU).
<g1>Name</g1>: the profile key (the thing being profiled) <x1/>

The color of the profiler text

If you select <g1>CPU</g1> as the display mode, the profiler displays:
If you select <g1>CPU</g1> as the display mode, the profiler displays:

<g1>Peak</g1>: the peak memory use since the game started
<g1>Peak</g1>: the peak memory use since the game started

<g1>Allocations</g1>: the amount of memory allocated or freed since the profiler last refreshed

RenderDoc is a free MIT licensed stand-alone graphics debugger that allows quick and easy single-frame capture and detailed introspection of any application using Vulkan, D3D11, OpenGL & OpenGL ES or D3D12 across Windows 7 - 10, Linux, Android, or Nintendo Switch™.

As CPU and GPU process different types of data, it's usually easy to identify which part is causing a bottleneck.
As CPU and GPU process different types of data, it's usually easy to identify which part is causing a bottleneck.
Most GPU problems arise when the application uses expensive rendering techniques, such as post effects, lighting, shadows, and tessellation.
Most GPU problems arise when the application uses expensive rendering techniques, such as post effects, lighting, shadows, and tessellation.
To identify the problem, disable rendering features.
To identify the problem, disable rendering features.
If instead there seems to be a CPU bottleneck, reduce the complexity of the scene.
If instead there seems to be a CPU bottleneck, reduce the complexity of the scene.
decrease the resolution of your game
decrease the resolution of your game
reduce the quality of your <g1>post effects</g1>
reduce the quality of your <g1>post effects</g1>
reduce the number of lights and size of <g1>shadow maps</g1>
reduce the number of lights and size of <g1>shadow maps</g1>
use culling techniques to reduce the number of objects and vertices rendered
use culling techniques to reduce the number of objects and vertices rendered
use sprite sheets, not individual images
use sprite sheets, not individual images
use texture atlases, not separate textures
use texture atlases, not separate textures
